{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=June 2018}} {{advert|date=June 2018}} }} {{Coord|37|47|19|N|122|25|26|W|region:US|display=title}} {{Infobox school | name = Institute for Advanced Study of Human Sexuality | streetaddress = 1523 Franklin Street (at Austin St.) | city = [[San Francisco]] | state = [[California]] | zipcode = | country = USA | type = | established = 1976 | founder = | president = | chair = | dean = | administrator = | teaching_staff = | employees = | enrollment = | enrollment_as_of = | nickname = | accreditation = None | publication = ''[[Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality]]'' | budget = | fees = | tuition = $21,450 per year | graduates = | website = {{url|www.humansexualityeducation.com}} }} The '''Institute for Advanced Study of Human Sexuality''' (est. 1976) is an [[Unaccredited institutions of higher education|unaccredited]],[[U.S. Department of Education]] [http://ope.ed.gov/accreditation/ "Database of Accredited Postsecondary Institutions and Programs]. for-profit, degree-granting institution and resource center in the field of [[sexology]] located in [[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.iashs.edu/ |title=Institute for the Advanced Study of Human Sexuality |accessdate=2009-10-22 }} Degree and certificate programs focus on [[public health]], [[sex therapy]], and sexological research. The Institute grew out of research in the 1960s highlighting the general lack of understanding of and formal training in human sexuality. The library and archives are a collection of [[Pornographic film|adult films]], academic [[Sexology|sexological]] and erotological resources, and [[sex therapy]] training materials. The IASHS has trained many of the current directors of sexology programs in other countries. Most recently, a sister school of the IASHS has been launched in China. Like all post-secondary schools in California, IASHS is required by California law to register with the State of California [[Bureau for Private Postsecondary Education]], an anti-fraud or anti-[[diploma mill]] unit of the [[California Department of Consumer Affairs]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bppe.ca.gov/schools/accredited_institutions.shtml|title=Approval by Means of Accreditation Overview|publisher=Bureau for Private Postsecondary Education|accessdate=5 April 2013 |quote=
'''Q'''. Does the Bureau accredit institutions?
'''A'''. No. The Bureau approves a person to operate an institution in California. An approval to operate signifies that an institution is in compliance with state standards as set forth in the Private Postsecondary Education Act. Only accrediting agencies can accredit an institution. Accreditation is a voluntary non-governmental review process. On the other hand, state approval is mandatory for a person operating an institution subject to the [[California Private Postsecondary Education Act of 2009]].}} IASHS has BPPE "approval to operate", which means that IASHS meets the minimum legal standards for "offering of ''bona fide'' instruction by qualified faculty".{{cite web|url=https://app.dca.ca.gov/bppe/default.asp|title=Approved Institutions|publisher=Bureau for Private Postsecondary Education|accessdate=5 April 2013}} == History == The path that led to the founding of the Institute for Advanced Study of Human Sexuality in 1976 began in 1962 with a program called the National Young Adult Project (NYAP). Originating in the then Methodist Church, the NYAP ultimately became an ecumenical project that included the Evangelical United Brethren, Presbyterian Church USA, and United Church of Christ denominations on the national level. Other church bodies (African Methodist Episcopal, American Baptist, Lutheran Church Missouri Synod, Protestant Episcopal, United Presbyterian Church in the USA, and Lutheran Church of America) also participated on a regional or local level. Dr. Ted McIlvenna, a Methodist minister, and cofounder, owner and president of the Institute, headed the San Francisco project for the NYAP. Of the 50+ nationwide projects the NYAP developed by 1968, only the three connected to him and to Glide Memorial Methodist Church had anything to do with sexuality issues. McIlvenna believed that there was a lack of research on human sexuality and the absence of demonstrated effective training and educational methodologies. A meeting in 1967 at the [[Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction|Institute for Sex Research]] led to the formation of the National Sex Forum as part of the [[Glide Foundation]] to address this lack. By 1974, it was clear to the Forum that a free-standing institute dedicated to the study of and education and training in the emerging field of [[sexology]] was required. They divided the creation of the academic institute as: McIlvenna to re-envision the Forum as an academic setting; Laird Sutton to collect a graphic-resource library; Herbert Vandervoort to organize and prepare the academic work of the study team; and Marguerite Rubenstein, Loretta Haroian, and Phyllis Lyon to define the professional training standards for the new academically trained professional sexologists.{{cite book |author1=Bullough, Bonnie |author2=Bullough, Vern L. |title=Human sexuality: an encyclopedia |publisher=Garland Pub |location=New York |year=1994 |pages=310–312 |isbn=0-8240-7972-8 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} [[Wardell Pomeroy]] was the first Academic Dean.{{cite web|url=http://www2.hu-berlin.de/sexology/GESUND/ARCHIV/CHR07.HTM#kopf |title=Archive for Sexology: Modern Sex Research (1938– ) |accessdate=2009-10-23 |publisher=Magnus Hirschfeld Archive for Sexology at Humboldt University }} The Institute was integral to the development of ''[[Humanistic psychology|humanistic sexology]]'', emphasizing experiential techniques and sexual pleasure over positivist empiricism. The culture of casual as well as clinical nudity and the inclusion of various [[Bodywork (alternative medicine)|bodywork]] and [[erotic massage]] techniques led to the Institute being nicknamed "Fuck U" by some critics.{{cite book |author=Irvine, Janice M. |title=Disorders of desire: sexuality and gender in modern American sexology |publisher=Temple University Press |location=Philadelphia |year=2005 |pages= |isbn=1-59213-151-4 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} The inclusion of [[Reichian therapy]] and other techniques not well founded in research has similarly led to criticism. == Academics == Degrees are offered in Master of Human Sexuality, Master of Public Health in Human Sexuality, and Doctor of Human Sexuality, as well as Doctor of Education and Doctor of Philosophy degrees with a focus in sexology and erotology. They also offer [[Professional certification|professional certificates]] in: Associate in [[Sex Education]], [[Clinical Sexology]], [[Sexological Bodywork]], Sexological Instructor/Advisor of AIDS/[[STI Prevention]], [[Sex Coaching]], and [[Erotology]] Certificates. Coursework varies by degree sought, but includes formal academic lectures, group-based discussion, video lectures and webinars (which may be undertaken off-site as part of a [[distance education]] program), and hands-on training in therapy and [[Bodywork (alternative medicine)|bodywork]]. Research-based degrees include independent or directed use of the Institute's extensive primary and secondary archives of sexological material.[http://www.humansexualityeducation.com/courses.html] Almost all of the faculty listed on the Institute's website obtained their most advanced degree from the Institute.http://www.humansexualityeducation.com/faculty-administration.html == Accreditation == The Institute is not accredited. The Institute's FAQ page, in response to the question "Is the Institute an accredited academic institution?", states that the Institute is approved by the [[California Bureau for Private Postsecondary Education]] (BPPE).[https://app.dca.ca.gov/bppe/view-school.asp?schlcode=3800061 Database record for IASHS] However, the BPPE is not an [[List of recognized higher education accreditation organizations#United States|accrediting agency]]; the agency's main focus is on identifying [[diploma mills]].{{cite news| url=http://finance.boston.com/boston/news/read?GUID=17952325 | work=The Boston Globe | title=More financial news | date=2009-08-24}}ftp://leginfo.ca.gov/pub/11-12/bill/sen/sb_0651-0700/sb_675_cfa_20110428_143825_sen_comm.html In July 2014, the BPPE sent a [http://www.bppe.ca.gov/enforcement/actions/ntc_3800061.pdf Notice to Comply] to IASHS regarding several violations. In early 2016, the California Bureau for Private Postsecondary Education sent a [http://www.bppe.ca.gov/enforcement/actions/citation_1516058.pdf Citation: Assessment of Fine and Order of Abatement] to IASHS, for seven violations. As of September 2014, IASHS is required by [https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201320140SB1247 CA SB1247] to seek and obtain accreditation. [[Quackwatch]] identifies the Institute as a "Questionable Organization".http://www.quackwatch.com/04ConsumerEducation/nonrecorg.html Students at unaccredited institutions are never eligible for [[Student financial aid (United States)|financial aid]], including [[student loans]], through any government agency. In some states, it can be illegal to use a degree from an unaccredited institution, unless approved by the state licensing agency.U.S. Department of Education, [http://www.ed.gov/students/prep/college/diplomamills/accreditation.html Diploma Mills and Accreditation] “We don’t take federal money and that’s why we won’t be accredited by the traditional state agencies. We don’t want to be handcuffed as to what we can provide, say and do. We’ve been approached by accrediting bodies run by Mormons and Roman Catholics that wanted us to change our code of ethics to promote contraception and change our name to reflect ‘family and marriage counseling’ instead of sexuality. We won’t do it,” according to IASHS founder Dr. Ted McIlvenna.http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php == Activities == In addition to its educational and archival mission, the Institute engages in outreach, such as teaching [[sex education]] to underserved teenagers in demographics at high risk for [[Teenage pregnancy|pregnancy]]. Ted McIlvenna, president of the Institute, favors a curriculum focusing on teaching teenagers techniques for "obtaining healthy, respectful relationships with their partners" rather than [[abstinence-only sex education]].{{cite news | first=Phil | last=Busse | title=Birds don't do it, Bees don't do it: Surprise! The Feds don't want teens having sex | date=2002-09-26 | publisher= | url =http://www.portlandmercury.com/news/birds-dont-do-itbees-dont-do-it/Content?oid=27637 | work =The Portland Mercury | pages = | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | language = }} The Institute has produced [[safe sex]] books, videos, and assorted paraphernalia. The archives include hundreds of thousands of adult films, as well as documents tracing the development of sexology as a field of research and training and educational materials; together, they comprise one of the most comprehensive sexological and erotological resource centers in the world.{{cite news | first=David | last=Louie | title=Armory Protest Reveals S.F. Porn Industry: S.F. has 6 of 10 top companies | date=2007-02-08 | publisher=[[ABC News]] | url =http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local&id=5014974 | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | language = }}{{cite news | title=Human Sexuality: institute studies sex to improve lifestyles | date=1978-08-15 | publisher= | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ze4VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LBMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6530,2819044&dq=institute-for-advanced-study-of-human-sexuality | work =Wilmington Morning Star | pages = | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | language = }}{{cite encyclopedia |author=Ted McIlvenna |editor1=Erwin J. Haeberle |editor2=Vern L. Bullough |editor3=Bonnie Bullough |encyclopedia=Human Sexuality: An Encyclopedia |title=Institute for the Advanced Study of Human Sexuality |url=http://www2.hu-berlin.de/sexology/GESUND/ARCHIV/SEN/CH13.HTM#b7-INSTITUTE%20FOR%20ADVANCED%20STUDY%20OF%20HUMAN%20SEXUALITY |accessdate=2009-10-24 |edition= |date= |year= |publisher=Garland Publishing, Inc. |volume= |location= |id= |doi= |pages= |quote= }} IASHS helped to establish the Erotic Heritage Museum in Las Vegas, in partnership with Harry Moheny, and offered a rotating selection of films and other art are on display at the [[Erotic Heritage Museum]].{{cite news | first=Lynette | last=Curtis | title=Embracing Erotic Art: New museum's exhibits, films, sculptures and photos celebrate human sexuality | date=2008-07-28 | publisher= | url =http://www.lvrj.com/news/25958069.html | work =Las Vegas Review Journal | pages = | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | language = }} However, [http://www.eroticmuseumvegas.com/museum/ the museum is now owned and managed by Harry Mohney]. The Institute favors open discussion of sexuality, including such issues as [[oral sex]], [[masturbation]], [[homosexuality]], [[BDSM]] and informed consent, teen sex and pregnancy, and [[sex therapy]]. Roger Libby, adjunct professor, sex therapist, and author of ''The Naked Truth About Sex: A Guide to Intelligent Sexual Choices for Teenagers and Twentysomethings'', encourages the use of extensive pre-sex discussions to set parameters and establish comfort levels.{{cite news | first=Regina | last=Lynn | title=The Naked Truth About Sex Ed | date=2006-06-16 | publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | url =https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/commentary/sexdrive/2006/06/71158 | work =Sex Drive | pages = | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | language = }}{{cite book |author=Libby, Roger W. |title=The Naked Truth About Sex: A Guide to Intelligent Sexual Choices for Teenagers and Twentysomethings |publisher=Freedom Press (CA) |location= |year=2006 |pages= |isbn=1-893910-38-5 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} [[Charles Allen Moser|Charles Moser]], chair of IASHS Department of Sexual Medicine, has argued that [[paraphilia]]s and BDSM should be removed from the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]]'' (DSM).Moser C, Kleinplatz PJ (2005). DSM-IV-TR and the Paraphilias: An argument for removal. ''Journal of Psychology and Human Sexuality'', 17(3/4), 91-109.{{cite news | first=John | last=Cloud | title=Bondage Unbound | date=2004-01-18 | publisher= | url =http://www.time.com/time/2004/sex/article/bondage_unbound_growing01b.html | work =[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | language = }} === ''Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality'' === The Institute published the ''[[Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality]]'' each year until its final issue in 2014. Articles were reviewed by the editorial board with supplemental review by readers.{{cite web|url=http://www.ejhs.org/ |title=The Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality |accessdate=2009-10-22 }} == Notable graduates == Notable graduates include: *[[Gloria Brame]], sex therapist, author. *[[Ava Cadell]], sex therapist, author, co-founder of [https://avacadell.com/home Loveology University]. *[[Betty Dodson]], sex educator, author. * [[David Lourea]], bisexual activist. * [[Sharon Mitchell]] founded the [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]], an organization supporting regular testing of [[pornographic actor]]s for [[HIV]] and other [[Sexually transmitted disease|sexually transmitted infections]].{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?&res=9C05EEDF123CF933A25756C0A9629C8B63 |title=Voice of Health in a Pornographic World |accessdate=2007-02-26 |author=Nick Madigan |date=2004-05-10 |publisher=New York Times |quote=
Sharon Mitchell — ''Well-behaved women rarely make history''}}{{cite news | first=Tim | last=Walker | title=Life after porn | date=2008-05-29 | publisher= | url =https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/life-after-porn-836080.html | work =[[The Independent]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | language = | location=London}} *[[Laura Henkel]], founder of the [http://www.sincitygallery.com], [http://www.12ofsin.com], and [http://www.artculturepr.com], Las Vegas. *[[Carol Queen]], founder of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20121111111815/http://www.sexandculture.org/mission Center for Sex & Culture], San Francisco. *[[Annie Sprinkle]], sex educator.{{cite web | url = http://anniesprinkle.org/about/sprinkle_story.html | title = The Annie Sprinkle Story | accessdate = 2011-01-10}} *[[Lindsey Doe]], sexology educator, host and co-creator of online video series, ''Sexplanations.'' == See also == * [[History of erotic depictions]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.humansexualityeducation.com}} * [http://www.ejhs.org/ ''The Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality''], published by the institute {{DEFAULTSORT:Institute For Advanced Study Of Human Sexuality}} [[Category:Institute for Advanced Study of Human Sexuality| ]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1976]] [[Category:Sexology organizations]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in San Francisco]] [[Category:Sexual orientation and science]] [[Category:1976 establishments in California]] [[Category:Unaccredited institutions of higher learning in California]] [[Category:Sexuality in San Francisco]]

{{Infobox scientist |name = Joseph Jordania |image = Joseph Jordania in 2011.jpg |caption = Joseph Jordania in 2011 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1954|02|12}} |birth_place = [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] (now [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]) |residence = [[Melbourne]] |citizenship = |ethnicity = [[Australian]] and [[Georgian people|Georgian]] |field = [[ethnomusicology]], [[evolutionary musicology]], [[evolutionary psychology]], [[speech pathology]] |work_institution = [[University of Melbourne]] |alma_mater = [[Tbilisi State Conservatory]], [[Tbilisi State University]] |doctoral_advisor = Grigol Chkhikvadze |doctoral_students = |known_for = The original model of the origins of choral singing in the context of human evolution; Notion of the "[[Battle trance]]"; [[Aposematism|Aposematic]] model of human evolution |prizes = [[Fumio Koizumi Prize for ethnomusicology]] (2009), [[Centenary Medal]] of Australia (2003) |website = [http://www.josephjordania.com Joseph Jordania Website] }} '''Joseph Jordania''' (born February 12, 1954 and also known under the misspelling of '''Joseph Zhordania''') is an [[Australian]]–[[Georgian people|Georgian]] [[ethnomusicologist]] and [[evolution]]ary [[musicologist]] and professor.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gelzer: Local Teacher Makes Mark On Georgian Folk Music|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5S0zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RggGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6953,2060057&dq=joseph-jordania&hl=en|accessdate=31 August 2013|newspaper=The Free Lance-Star|date=Nov 8, 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Journal of the Institute of Musicology of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Issue 5|year=2005|publisher=Muzikološki institut SANU|pages=197, 198|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DrifAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Joseph+Jordania%22&dq=%22Joseph+Jordania%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BcYhUsGmGZSu4APvu4CgCg&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBzgK}}</ref> He is an Honorary Fellow of the Melbourne Conservatorium of Music at the [[University of Melbourne]] and the Head of the Foreign Department of the [[International Research Centre for Traditional Polyphony]] at [[Tbilisi State Conservatory]]. Jordania is known for his model of the origins of human [[choral singing]] in the wide context of [[human evolution]] and was one of founders of the [[International Research Centre for Traditional Polyphony]] in Georgia.
Jordania’s academic interests include study of worldwide distribution of choral [[polyphonic]] traditions, origins of [[choral singing]], origins of [[rhythm]], origins of human [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] and [[behaviour]], cross-cultural prevalence of [[stuttering]], [[dyslexia]] and acquisition of [[phonological]] system in children, study of the [[cognitive]] threshold between animal and human cognitive abilities. His primary expertise is Georgian and Caucasian traditional music and vocal polyphony.
==Career== Jordania was born in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] (former [[Soviet Union]]). He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] degree in [[ethnomusicology]] from [[Tbilisi State Conservatory]] in 1978. During 1979–1983 he was elected as the President of the Board of Creative Youth of Tbilisi. In 1982 he received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] degree in [[musicology]]–[[ethnomusicology]] from Tbilisi Theatrical Institute, and served as lecturer, senior lecturer, assistant professor, and professor at the Department of Georgian Traditional Music at [[Tbilisi State Conservatory]]. For one year (in 1984) he served as a dean of the Faculty of Musicology. In 1991 he received the title [[D.Mus]] from [[Kiev Conservatory]]. From 1988 until 1995 Jordania was the head of the Musical Sector of the Centre of the Mediterranean Studies at the Tbilisi State University. He published his first monograph on choral polyphony in 1989. In 1984 he was instrumental in organizing the conference "Problems of Folk Polyphony". This conference became the beginning of the series of biannual international conferences (1984, 1986, 1988, 1998, 2000) and symposia (2002, 2004, 2006, 2010, 2012, 2014, 2016) on traditional polyphony, and led to establishing the [[International Research Centre for Traditional Polyphony]] at Tbilisi State Conservatory in 2003.<ref>{{cite book|last=Doijašvili|first=Manana|title=The Vano Saradjishvili Tbilisi State Conservatoire, 1917-2007|year=2008|publisher=[[Nova Science Publishers, Inc.]]|isbn=1600219101|page=75|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OWOM8ia2-2wC&pg=PA75&dq=%22Joseph+Jordania%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-sUhUs-hFfLh4AP8wYHoDQ&ved=0CFIQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22Joseph%20Jordania%22&f=false}}</ref>
In 2009, in recognition of "his contribution to systematic analysis of folk polyphonies of the world, proposing a new model for the origins of traditional choral singing in a broad context of human evolution" Jordania was awarded the [[Fumio Koizumi Prize for ethnomusicology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geidai.ac.jp/labs/koizumi/awarde/21jj1e.html|title=21st Annual (2009) Koizumi Fumio Prize|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Koizumi Fumio Prize|accessdate=31 August 2013}}</ref>

[[Image:FinitePolytropes.svg|thumb|Solutions of Lane–Emden equation for ''n'' = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]]
In [[astrophysics]], the '''Lane–Emden equation''' is a dimensionless form of [[Poisson's equation]] for the gravitational potential of a Newtonian self-gravitating, spherically symmetric, [[polytropic]] fluid. It is named after astrophysicists [[Jonathan Homer Lane]] and [[Robert Emden]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lane|first=Jonathan Homer|title=On the Theoretical Temperature of the Sun under the Hypothesis of a Gaseous Mass Maintaining its Volume by its Internal Heat and Depending on the Laws of Gases Known to Terrestrial Experiment|journal=The American Journal of Science and Arts|date=1870|volume=50|series=2|pages=57–74|author-link=Jonathan Homer Lane}}</ref> The equation reads
: <math> \frac{1}{\xi^2} \frac{d}{d\xi} \left({\xi^2 \frac{d\theta}{d\xi}}\right) + \theta^n = 0, </math>
where <math>\xi</math> is a dimensionless radius and <math>\theta</math> is related to the density, and thus the pressure, by <math>\rho=\rho_c\theta^n</math> for central density <math>\rho_c</math>. The index <math>n</math> is the polytropic index that appears in the polytropic equation of state,
: <math> P = K \rho^{1 + \frac{1}{n}}\, </math>
where <math>P</math> and <math>\rho</math> are the pressure and density, respectively, and <math>K</math> is a constant of proportionality. The standard boundary conditions are <math>\theta(0)=1</math> and <math>\theta'(0)=0</math>. Solutions thus describe the run of pressure and density with radius and are known as ''polytropes'' of index <math>n</math>. If an isothermal fluid (polytropic index tends to infinity) is used instead of a polytropic fluid, one obtains the [[Emden–Chandrasekhar equation]].
== Applications == Physically, hydrostatic equilibrium connects the gradient of the potential, the density, and the gradient of the pressure, whereas Poisson's equation connects the potential with the density. Thus, if we have a further equation that dictates how the pressure and density vary with respect to one another, we can reach a solution. The particular choice of a polytropic gas as given above makes the mathematical statement of the problem particularly succinct and leads to the Lane–Emden equation. The equation is a useful approximation for self-gravitating spheres of plasma such as stars, but typically it is a rather limiting assumption.
== Derivation ==
=== From hydrostatic equilibrium === Consider a self-gravitating, spherically symmetric fluid in [[hydrostatic equilibrium]]. Mass is conserved and thus described by the [[continuity equation]]
: <math> \frac{dm}{dr} = 4\pi r^2 \rho </math>
where <math>\rho</math> is a function of <math>r</math>. The equation of hydrostatic equilibrium is
: <math> \frac{1}{\rho}\frac{dP}{dr} = -\frac{Gm}{r^2} </math>
where <math>m</math> is also a function of <math>r</math>. Differentiating again gives
: <math>\begin{align} \frac{d}{dr}\left(\frac{1}{\rho}\frac{dP}{dr}\right) &= \frac{2Gm}{r^3}-\frac{G}{r^2}\frac{dm}{dr} \\ &=-\frac{2}{\rho r}\frac{dP}{dr}-4\pi G\rho \end{align}</math>
where the continuity equation has been used to replace the mass gradient. Multiplying both sides by <math>r^2</math> and collecting the derivatives of <math>P</math> on the left, one can write
: <math> r^2\frac{d}{dr}\left(\frac{1}{\rho}\frac{dP}{dr}\right)+\frac{2r}{\rho}\frac{dP}{dr} = \frac{d}{dr}\left(\frac{r^2}{\rho}\frac{dP}{dr}\right)=-4\pi Gr^2\rho </math>
Dividing both sides by <math>r^2</math> yields, in some sense, a dimensional form of the desired equation. If, in addition, we substitute for the polytropic equation of state with <math>P=K\rho_c^{1+\frac{1}{n}}\theta^{n+1}</math> and <math>\rho=\rho_c\theta^n</math>, we have
: <math> \frac{1}{r^2}\frac{d}{dr}\left(r^2K\rho_c^\frac{1}{n}(n+1)\frac{d\theta}{dr}\right)=-4\pi G\rho_c\theta^n</math>
Gathering the constants and substituting <math>r=\alpha\xi</math>, where
: <math>\alpha^2=(n+1)K\rho_c^{\frac{1}{n}-1}/4\pi G,</math>
we have the Lane–Emden equation,
: <math> \frac{1}{\xi^2} \frac{d}{d\xi} \left({\xi^2 \frac{d\theta}{d\xi}}\right) + \theta^n = 0 </math>
=== From Poisson's equation ===
Equivalently, one can start with [[Poisson's equation]],
: <math> \nabla^2\Phi=\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{d}{dr}\left( r^2\frac{d\Phi}{dr} \right) = 4\pi G\rho </math>
One can replace the gradient of the potential using the hydrostatic equilibrium, via
: <math> \frac{d\Phi}{dr}= - \frac{1}{\rho}\frac{dP}{dr} </math>
which again yields the dimensional form of the Lane–Emden equation.
==Exact Solutions== For a given value of the polytropic index <math>n</math>, denote the solution to the Lane–Emden equation as <math>\theta_n(\xi)</math>. In general, the Lane–Emden equation must be solved numerically to find <math>\theta_n</math>. There are exact, analytic solutions for certain values of <math>n</math>, in particular: <math>n = 0,1,5</math>. For <math>n</math> between 0 and 5, the solutions are continuous and finite in extent, with the radius of the star given by <math>R = \alpha \xi_1 </math>, where <math>\theta_n(\xi_1) = 0</math>.
For a given solution <math>\theta_n</math>, the density profile is given by
: <math> \rho = \rho_c \theta_n^n </math>.
The total mass <math>M</math> of the model star can be found by integrating the density over radius, from 0 to <math>\xi_1</math>.
The pressure can be found using the polytropic equation of state, <math>P = K \rho^{1+\frac{1}{n}} </math>, i.e.
: <math> P = K \rho_c^{1+\frac{1}{n}} \theta_n^{n+1}</math>
Finally, if the gas is [[ideal gas law|ideal]], the equation of state is <math>P = k_B\rho T/\mu</math>, where <math>k_B</math> is the [[Boltzmann constant]] and <math>\mu</math> the mean molecular weight. The temperature profile is then given by
: <math> T = \frac{K\mu}{k_B} \rho_c^{1/n} \theta_n </math>
In spherically symmetric cases, the Lane–Emden equation is integrable for only three values of the polytropic index <math>n</math>.
=== For ''n'' = 0 === If <math>n=0</math>, the equation becomes
: <math> \frac{1}{\xi^2} \frac{d}{d\xi} \left( \xi^2 \frac{d\theta}{d\xi} \right) + 1 = 0 </math>
Re-arranging and integrating once gives
: <math> \xi^2\frac{d\theta}{d\xi} = C_1-\frac{1}{3}\xi^3 </math>
Dividing both sides by <math>\xi^2</math> and integrating again gives
: <math> \theta(\xi)=C_0-\frac{C_1}{\xi}-\frac{1}{6}\xi^2 </math>
The boundary conditions <math>\theta(0)=1</math> and <math>\theta'(0)=0</math> imply that the constants of integration are <math>C_0=1</math> and <math>C_1=0</math>. Therefore,
: <math> \theta(\xi) = 1 - \frac{1}{6}\xi^2</math>
=== For ''n'' = 1 === When <math>n=1</math>, the equation can be expanded in the form
: <math> \frac{d^2\theta}{d\xi^2}+\frac{2}{\xi}\frac{d\theta}{d\xi} + \theta = 0 </math>
One assumes a power series solution:
:<math> \theta(\xi)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n \xi^n </math>
This leads to a recursive relationship for the expansion coefficients:
:<math> a_{n+2} = -\frac{a_n}{(n+3)(n+2)} </math>
This relation can be solved leading to the general solution:
: <math> \theta(\xi)=a_0 \frac{\sin\xi}{\xi} + a_1 \frac{\cos\xi}{\xi} </math>
The boundary condition for a physical polytrope demands that <math> \theta(\xi) \rightarrow 1</math> as <math> \xi \rightarrow 0 </math>. This requires that <math> a_0 = 1, a_1 = 0 </math>, thus leading to the solution:
:<math> \theta(\xi)=\frac{\sin\xi}{\xi} </math>
=== For ''n'' = 5 === We start from with the Lane–Emden equation:
: <math> \frac1{\xi^2} {\frac{d}{d\xi}} \left(\xi^2\frac{d\theta}{d\xi}\right) + \theta^5 = 0 </math>
====Schuster's integral====
Rewriting for <math> \frac{d\theta}{d\xi} </math> produces:
: <math> \frac{d\theta} {d\xi} = \frac1 2 \left(1+\frac{\xi^2}{3}\right)^{3/2} \frac{2\xi} 3 = \frac {\xi^3}{3 \left[ 1+\frac {\xi^2} 3 \right]^{3/2}} </math>
Differentiating with respect to ''ξ'' leads to:
: <math> \theta^5 =\frac{\xi^2}{\left[1+\frac{\xi^2}{3}\right]^{3/2}} + \frac{3\xi^2}{9\left[1+\frac{\xi^2}3\right]^{5/2}} = \frac 9 {9\left[1+\frac{\xi^2}3\right]^{5/2}} </math>
Reduced, we come by:
: <math> \theta^5 = \frac 1 { \left[ 1+\frac{\xi^2}3 \right]^{5/2}} </math>
Therefore, the Lane–Emden equation has the solution
: <math> \theta(\xi)=\frac 1 {\sqrt{1+\xi^2/3}} </math>
when <math>n=5</math>. This solution is finite in mass but infinite in radial extent, and therefore the complete polytrope does not represent a physical solution. Chandrasekhar believed for a long time that finding other solution for <math>n=5</math> "is complicated and involves elliptic integrals".
====Srivastava's solution==== In 1962, Sambhunath Srivastava found an explicit solution when <math>n=5</math>.<ref>Srivastava, S. (1962). A New Solution of the Lane-Emden Equation of Index n= 5. The Astrophysical Journal, 136, 680-681.</ref> His solution is given by
:<math>\theta = \frac{\sin(\ln \sqrt \xi)}{\sqrt\xi[3-2 \sin^2 (\ln \sqrt\xi)]},</math>
and from this solution, a family of solutions <math>\theta(\xi)\rightarrow \sqrt A\, \theta(A\xi)</math> can be obtained using homology transformation. Since this solution does not satisfy the conditions at the origin (in fact, it is oscillatory with amplitudes growing indefinitely as the origin is approached), this solution can be used in composite stellar models.
== Numerical solutions == In general, solutions are found by numerical integration. Many standard methods require that the problem is formulated as a system of first-order [[ordinary differential equation]]s. For example,
: <math> \begin{align} & \frac{d\theta}{d\xi}=-\frac{\varphi}{\xi^2} \\[6pt] & \frac{d\varphi}{d\xi}=\theta^n\xi^2 \end{align} </math>
Here, <math>\varphi(\xi)</math> is interpreted as the dimensionless mass, defined by <math>m(r)=4\pi\alpha^3\rho_c\varphi(\xi)</math>. The relevant initial conditions are <math>\varphi(0)=0</math> and <math>\theta(0)=1</math>. The first equation represents hydrostatic equilibrium and the second represents mass conservation.
== Homologous variables ==
=== Homology-invariant equation === It is known that if <math>\theta(\xi)</math> is a solution of the Lane–Emden equation, then so is <math>C^{2/n+1}\theta(C\xi)</math>.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chandrasekhar|first=Subrahmanyan|title=An introduction to the study of stellar structure|date=1939|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|location=Chicago, Ill.|bibcode=1939isss.book.....C|author-link=Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar}}</ref> Solutions that are related in this way are called ''homologous''; the process that transforms them is ''homology''. If one chooses variables that are invariant to homology, then we can reduce the order of the Lane–Emden equation by one.
A variety of such variables exist. A suitable choice is
: <math>U=\frac{d\log m}{d\log r}=\frac{\xi^3\theta^n} \varphi </math>
and
: <math>V=\frac{d\log P}{d\log r}=(n+1)\frac \varphi {\xi\theta}</math>
We can differentiate the logarithms of these variables with respect to <math>\xi</math>, which gives
: <math>\frac{1}{U}\frac{dU}{d\xi}=\frac 1 \xi (3-n(n+1)^{-1}V-U)</math> and : <math>\frac{1}{V}\frac{dV}{d\xi}=\frac 1 \xi (-1+U+(n+1)^{-1}V)</math>.
Finally, we can divide these two equations to eliminate the dependence on <math>\xi</math>, which leaves
: <math>\frac{dV}{dU}=-\frac{V}{U}\left(\frac{U+(n+1)^{-1}V-1}{U+n(n+1)^{-1}V-3}\right)</math>
This is now a single first-order equation.
=== Topology of the homology-invariant equation ===
The homology-invariant equation can be regarded as the autonomous pair of equations
: <math>\frac{dU}{d\log\xi}=-U(U+n(n+1)^{-1}V-3)</math>
and
: <math>\frac{dV}{d\log\xi}=V(U+(n+1)^{-1}V-1).</math>
The behaviour of solutions to these equations can be determined by linear stability analysis. The critical points of the equation (where <math>dV/d\log\xi=dU/d\log\xi=0</math>) and the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the [[Jacobian matrix]] are tabulated below.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Horedt|first=Georg P.|title=Topology of the Lane-Emden equation|journal=[[Astronomy and Astrophysics]]|date=1987|volume=117|issue=1-2|pages=117–130|bibcode=1987A&A...177..117H}}</ref>
: <math> \begin{array}{|l|l|l|} \hline \text{Critical point} & \text{Eigenvalues} & \text{Eigenvectors} \\ \hline (0,0) & 3, -1 & (1,0), (0,1) \\ (3,0) & -3,2 & (1,0), (-3n,5+5n) \\ (0,n+1) & 1, 3-n & (0,1), (2-n,1+n) \\ \left(\dfrac{n-3}{n-1},2\dfrac{n+1}{n-1}\right) & \dfrac{n-5\pm\Delta_n}{2-2n} & (1-n\mp\Delta_n,4+4n) \\ \hline \end{array} </math>

== Basic information == === Lichens and Nitrogen Cycle === The [[nitrogen cycle]] is one of the Earth’s biogeochemical cycle that involves the conversion of nitrogen into different chemical forms. The main processes of the nitrogen cycle are the fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification. As one of the macronutrients, nitrogen plays an important role in plant growth. Both nitrogen-fixing lichens and non-nitrogen fixing lichens absorb the nitrogen as the one of the nutrient.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Seneviratne|first=Gamini|last2=Indrasena|first2=I. K.|date=December 2006|title=Nitrogen fixation in lichens is important for improved rock weathering|journal=Journal of Biosciences|volume=31|issue=5|pages=639–643|issn=0250-5991|pmid=17301502}}</ref> Different environments have different factors that contributes or affect the nitrogen cycle. For example, in the subarctic heath, increase in temperature can cause N2 fixation to increase or decrease based on season while overall climate warming indirectly caused the vegetation change which in turn affected of the N2 fixation process.<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal|last=Lett|first=Signe|last2=Michelsen|first2=Anders|date=2014-06-01|title=Seasonal variation in nitrogen fixation and effects of climate change in a subarctic heath|journal=Plant and Soil|volume=379|issue=1–2|pages=193–204|doi=10.1007/s11104-014-2031-y|issn=0032-079X}}</ref>
[[Lichen]]s are symbiotic organisms that play an important role in the biogeochemical cycle on Earth. Lichen's characteristic, such as strong resistances to factors such as desiccation, ability to grow and breakdown rocks allow lichen to grow in different types of environment including highly nitrogen limited area such as subarctic health.<ref name=":62" /><ref name=":52">{{Cite journal|last=Henriksson|first=Elisabet|last2=Simu|first2=Barbro|date=1971|title=Nitrogen Fixation by Lichens|jstor=3543371|journal=Oikos|volume=22|issue=1|pages=119–121|doi=10.2307/3543371}}</ref> While it does not occur often, formation of [[akinete]]s (type of cell formed by cyanobacteria which are resistant to cold and desiccation) was observed in N2 fixing lichen.<ref name=":52" /> Depending on its partner, lichens derive the carbon and nitrogen from algal and cyanobacteria photobionts (which fixes N2 from the air).<ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Dahlman|first=Lena|last2=Näsholm|first2=Torgny|last3=Palmqvist|first3=Kristin|date=2002-02-01|title=Growth, nitrogen uptake, and resource allocation in the two tripartite lichens Nephroma arcticum and Peltigera aphthosa during nitrogen stress|journal=New Phytologist|volume=153|issue=2|pages=307–315|doi=10.1046/j.0028-646X.2001.00321.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref> Lichen fungi can fix dinitrogen during the day and night, as long the dark period is not too long.<ref name=":52" />
=== Nitrogen-Fixing Lichens vs. Non-Nitrogen-Fixing Lichens === Both N2-fixing lichens and non-N2-fixing lichens take up nitrogen from the environment as nutrient. Both type of lichen secretes many different organic compounds to absorb minerals from the substrates.
Main difference between N2 fixing lichen and non-N2 fixing lichen is their photosynthetic partner. N2 fixing lichen is partnered with cyanobacteria which can fix N2 from the air while green alga, partner of non N2 fixing lichen, can't perform the same process.<ref name=":72">{{Cite journal|last=Henskens|first=F. L.|last2=Green|first2=T. G. A.|last3=Wilkins|first3=A.|date=2012-08-01|title=Cyanolichens can have both cyanobacteria and green algae in a common layer as major contributors to photosynthesis|url=https://academic.oup.com/aob/article/110/3/555/2769010|journal=Annals of Botany|volume=110|issue=3|pages=555–563|doi=10.1093/aob/mcs108|pmid=22648879|issn=0305-7364|pmc=3400443}}</ref> The nitrogen fixation is energetically costly due to chemical transformation and only about 10% of lichen are partnered with cyanobacteria.<ref name=":72" /><ref name=":82">{{Cite journal|last=Stam|first=Hein|last2=Stouthamer|first2=Adriaan H.|last3=van Verseveld|first3=Henk W.|date=1987-03-01|title=Hydrogen metabolism and energy costs of nitrogen fixation|journal=FEMS Microbiology Letters|volume=46|issue=1|pages=73–92|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6968.1987.tb02453.x|issn=1574-6968}}</ref> In agricultural region, non N2 fixing lichen reflect uptake of NH3 emission indicating that it have lower nitrogen value.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Marks|first=Jade A.|last2=Pett-Ridge|first2=Julie C.|last3=Perakis|first3=Steven S.|last4=Allen|first4=Jessica L.|last5=McCune|first5=Bruce|date=2015-09-01|title=Response of the nitrogen-fixing lichen Lobaria pulmonaria to phosphorus, molybdenum, and vanadium|journal=Ecosphere|volume=6|issue=9|pages=1–17|doi=10.1890/ES15-00140.1|issn=2150-8925}}</ref>
Some lichens such as Placopsis gelada contain both N2 fixing phototrophs and non N2-fixing phototrophs in which [[Nostoc]] (cyanobacteria, the phototrophic N2 fixer) was dwelling within [[Cephalodium|cephalodia]] (small gall like structure within lichen; contains cyanobacteria symbionts).<ref name=":02" /> In such cases, [[heterocyst]] differentiation was greater in cephalodia when compared to having Nostoc as the primary symbionts in lichens, showing that, in the presence of non N2-fixing phototroph, Nostoc specialize for N2 fixation.<ref name=":02" />
== Interaction with Lichen == === Response to Nitrogen and Phosphorus === Lichen's response to nutrient enrichment depends on not only on species and environmental factors but also partially on thallus concentrations of nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorus.<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Johansson|first=Otilia|last2=Olofsson|first2=Johan|last3=Giesler|first3=Reiner|last4=Palmqvist|first4=Kristin|date=2011-08-01|title=Lichen responses to nitrogen and phosphorus additions can be explained by the different symbiont responses|journal=New Phytologist|volume=191|issue=3|pages=795–805|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2011.03739.x|pmid=21534972|issn=1469-8137}}</ref>
Ammonium, nitrate and organic nitrogen can be assimilated by lichen along with phosphorus as an important stimulants for [[cyanolichen]]s. Photobiont will become less dependent of fungal nutrient supply when nitrogen deposition increases as it will be able to access its own nitrogen and it will stimulate photobiont, causing it to build up, resulting the increase in photosynthesis which increases carbon input.<ref name=":22" /> However, for lichens that cannot increase their photobiont growth, nitrogen deposition can be damaging due to higher nitrogen concentration than their biological requirements.<ref name=":22" />
Generally, when a lichenized algal cell is nitrogen limited, the addition of nitrogen caused the growth of algal cells.<ref name=":22" /> Under nitrogen limiting condition, chlorophyll concentration was positively correlated with the growth of algal cells indicating that should the concentration of chlorophyll increases, the photobiont population will also increase.<ref name=":22" /> As lichens absorb nitrogen through fixation, it will have a very strong negative reaction if the nitrogen availability changes indicating its sensitivity to environmental changes. According to the experiment by Sparrius et al., when nitrogen fertilizer was added into the soil, lichen cover was reduced by ~50%, while the addition of phosphorus showed opposite result.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Sparrius|first=Laurens B.|last2=Kooijman|first2=Annemieke M.|last3=Sevink|first3=Jan|date=2013-01-01|title=Response of inland dune vegetation to increased nitrogen and phosphorus levels|journal=Applied Vegetation Science|volume=16|issue=1|pages=40–50|doi=10.1111/j.1654-109X.2012.01206.x|issn=1654-109X}}</ref> In the region such as [[Taiga|boreal forest]], where nitrogen and phosphorus are limiting nutrients and for symbiotic interaction to occur properly, their ratio must be balanced.<ref name=":22" /> General pollution of climate that is indicated by the concentration of NOx can also affect the growth of lichen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hyvärinen|first=M.|last2=Crittenden|first2=P. D.|date=1998-11-01|title=Relationships between atmospheric nitrogen inputs and the vertical nitrogen and phosphorus concentration gradients in the lichen Cladonia portentosa|journal=New Phytologist|volume=140|issue=3|pages=519–530|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1998.00292.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref> When compared to [[bryophyte]] (non-vascular land plant), which is also sensitive to nitrogen fertilizer, lichen showed a much stronger response.<ref name=":12" />
=== Nitrogen Metabolism === There are many different species of lichens and each has its own way of allocating nitrogen. The non N2 fixing lichen invests a large amount of nitrogen into photosynthetic tissue, whereas N2 fixing lichen will invest into the fungal tissue.<ref name=":32" /> N2-fixing lichen species can only attain a certain amount of nitrogen as the addition of ammonium decreases its rate of N2-fixation, which decreases the amount of nitrogen that is exported into the adjacent [[hypha]]e.<ref name=":32" /> N2 fixation is energy dependent and very costly for lichens.<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|last=Millbank|first=J. W.|last2=Kershaw|first2=K. A.|date=1969-07-01|title=Nitrogen Metabolism in Lichens|journal=New Phytologist|volume=68|issue=3|pages=721–729|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1969.tb06476.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref> The lichens at the region where nitrogen deposition is high, have a lower uptake of nitrogen in comparison to the Antarctic green algal lichen, which takes up 90% of nitrogen deposition in both [[nitrate]] and [[ammonium]] form.<ref name=":32" /> Some lichen species are able to refrain from assimilating excessive amount of nitrogen in order to maintain a balanced tissue concentration.<ref name=":32" /> Majority of lichen species absorbs more NH4+ than NO3- and the impact of temperature on the rate of fixation is "consonant to the normal enzymatic kinetics of them".<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":42" />
=== Effects of Nitrogen Fixation === N2 fixing lIchens actively fixes atmospheric nitrogen using the [[Nostoc]], located in the [[Cephalodium|cephalodia]]. Lichens are sensitive to nitrogen availability.<ref name=":42" /> Upon nitrogen fixation, there will be an increase of algal cell growth, chlorophyll concentration, and photobiont population. While costly, in regions where nitrogen availability is low, fixation process is the main way for the lichen to absorb nitrogen which is [[Nutrient|macronutrient]] (essential nutrient).
== Importance == === Ecology === Nitrogen, as a macronutrient and a biogeochemical cycle, also affects the ecology. Through the nitrogen cycle, it breaks down into the chemical form that allows plants to absorb as nutrients. There are certain regions in the world that most plants can not live due to harsh environments as well as lack of nutrients such as nitrogen. That means that at in some regions, the biogeochemical cycle (including nitrogen cycle and carbon cycle) is unlikely to run smoothly. Lichen is able to absorb nitrogen is multiple forms from soil, rock, and air, taking a part in carbon cycle at the same time. Even though the only small fraction of lichens have the ability to fix nitrogen, it helps the lichen to spread throughout the world and survive even in the harsh environment.<ref name=":72" /><ref name=":82" />
The industrial nitrogen fertilizer greatly affected the vegetation and agriculture throughout the world, resulting significantly increased the amount of food with better quality, but it has a negative impact on ecology in the long run.<ref name=":102">{{Cite journal|last=Crews|first=T. E|last2=Peoples|first2=M. B|date=2004-05-01|title=Legume versus fertilizer sources of nitrogen: ecological tradeoffs and human needs|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167880903003402|journal=Agriculture, Ecosystems & Environment|volume=102|issue=3|pages=279–297|doi=10.1016/j.agee.2003.09.018}}</ref> Deposition of nitrogen causes the soil acidification and the nitrogens in the fertilizer are often leached through soil and water, running off the different area.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Riley|first=W. J.|last2=Ortiz-Monasterio|first2=I.|last3=Matson|first3=P. A.|date=2001-11-01|title=Nitrogen leaching and soil nitrate, nitrite, and ammonium levels under irrigated wheat in Northern Mexico|journal=Nutrient Cycling in Agroecosystems|volume=61|issue=3|pages=223–236|doi=10.1023/A:1013758116346|issn=1385-1314}}</ref><ref name=":92">{{Cite journal|last=Bowman|first=William D.|last2=Cleveland|first2=Cory C.|last3=Halada|first3=Ĺuboš|last4=Hreško|first4=Juraj|last5=Baron|first5=Jill S.|date=November 2008|title=Negative impact of nitrogen deposition on soil buffering capacity|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ngeo339|journal=Nature Geoscience|volume=1|issue=11|pages=767–770|doi=10.1038/ngeo339|issn=1752-0908}}</ref> Soil acidification result increase in toxicity of the soil which reduces plant biodiversity and based on the toxic level of soil acidification, heavy metal such as aluminum and iron can be related to soil water.<ref name=":92" />
=== Rock and Soil === Earth's mantle contains non-atmospheric nitrogen in the form of rocks and in the soil.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Halama|first=Ralf|last2=Bebout|first2=Gray E.|last3=John|first3=Timm|last4=Scambelluri|first4=Marco|date=2014-10-01|title=Nitrogen recycling in subducted mantle rocks and implications for the global nitrogen cycle|journal=International Journal of Earth Sciences|volume=103|issue=7|pages=2081–2099|doi=10.1007/s00531-012-0782-3|issn=1437-3254}}</ref> Weathering of the rocks and stone are normally caused by physical, chemical and biological processes. Plants cannot absorb nitrogen from rocks however, fungi can. Fungi within lichens can extract nutrients from mineral surfaces by secreting organic acids. The organic acids (e.g. phenolic acids) are important in solubilizing nutrients from inorganic substrates.<ref name=":02" /> A study was conducted to test rock phosphate solubilization by lichen-forming fungi. Bacteria that were attached to biotic or abiotic surfaces stimulate exopolysaccharide synthesis.<ref name=":02" /> While lichens have the ability to absorb nitrogen from rock, this only accounts for a small portion of the nitrogen cycle compared to the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen as it is more easily available.
=== Effects on Plants/Vegetation === Photobiont will become less dependent on fungal nutrient supply when nitrogen deposition increases as it will be able to access its own nitrogen and primary producers' nutrient limit will also be reduced.<ref name=":22" />
Nitrogen is one of the more limiting nutrients and the addition of nitrogen stimulate the photobiont, building up its cell, which subsequently increases its photosynthesis and its carbon input. Multiple nitrogen compounds can be assimilated by lichens, such as NH4+, NO3- and organic nitrogen compounds.<ref name=":22" /> Nitrogen deposition reduces the nutrient limitation of primary production. Increase in nitrogen deposition will allow the photobiont to access its own nitrogen which makes it less fungal dependent but only up to certain point.<ref name=":22" />
Depending on the environmental nitrogen availability, the addition of nitrogen can either increase and decrease the growth of the lichen. If the lichen cannot increase its photobiont growth, high nitrogen uptake may result in a higher concentration than it physiologically requires which will negatively affect the lichen and it's host plant as the other nutrients are too limiting.
Lichen’s response to nutrient enrichment is both species-specific and dependent its environmental factors e.g. nutrient concentration, light availability and water supply.<ref name=":22" />
== Nitrogen Stress == Lichen is nitrogen sensitive and change in nitrogen availability can affect its health greatly.
Two main nitrogen stress factors for lichens are nitrogen deficiency and high nitrogen deposition.<ref name=":32" /> Both types of nitrogen stress result in the reduction of the rate of thallus expansion in lichen. Nitrogen stressed lichen did not show the significant change in chitin: chlorophyll ratios but ergosterol concentration was showed significant increase indicating a higher load of respiratory.
The [[Haber process|Haber-Bosch process]] is the main industrial procedure for nitrogen fertilizer (ammonia) production today which is used for the agricultural purpose and it is stated that more than 5 billion people owe their existence to it.<ref name=":102" /> It has increased the food production and the farmers no longer have to sacrifice crop yield for nitrogen application not have to use [[Crop rotation|rotating sequence]].<ref name=":102" /> However, nitrogen deposition cause soil acidification as well as nitrogen [[Leaching (agriculture)|leaching]]. In the long term, use of nitrogen fertilizer causes the soil to acidify which reduce the crop performance due heavy metal toxicity and reduction of other nutrients.<ref name=":102" /> Leached nitrogen can also travel to other regions via water which will contaminate the water and affect plant biodiversity in the nearby areas such as forest or empty fields where lichens are likely to be present.
According to the experiment, the ammonium toxicity due to nitrogen deposition reduced the vitality of lichen greatly at different regions such as inland dunes, boreal conditions, and Antarctic heaths.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":12" />

{{about||the musical instrument|Mandola|the circular pattern in Buddhist tradition|Mandala}} {{expand language|topic=|langcode=de|otherarticle=|date=July 2016}} [[File:Codex Bruchsal 1 01v cropped.jpg|thumb|right|[[Christ in Majesty]] shown within a mandorla shape in a medieval [[illuminated manuscript]].]] A '''mandorla''' is an [[aureola]], or frame, usually in the shape of a [[vesica piscis]], which surrounds the figures of Christ and the Virgin Mary in traditional Christian art.<ref name="ref3">{{cite book | last = Liungman | first = Carl G. | title = Dictionary of Symbols | publisher = W.W. Norton | year = 1991 | page = 287 | isbn =0-393-31236-4 }}</ref> It is distinguished from a [[halo (religious iconography)|halo]] in that it encircles the entire body, and not just the head. It is commonly used to frame the figure of [[Christ in Majesty]] in early medieval and [[Romanesque art]], as well as [[Byzantine art]] of the same periods.
==Depictions== The term ''mandorla'', from the [[Italian language]] name for the "[[almond]]" nut, refers to the usual shape. Sometimes however, especially in earlier depictions, the mandorla takes circular or elliptical forms. Sometimes, also usually in earlier forms, the mandorla is shown as the intersection of two circles. [[Rhombus|Rhombic]] mandorlas are also sometimes seen.
In [[icon]]s of the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], the mandorla is used to depict sacred moments which transcend time and space, such as the [[Resurrection of Jesus|Resurrection]] and the [[Transfiguration of Jesus|Transfiguration]] of Christ and the [[Dormition of the Theotokos]]. These mandorla will often be painted in several concentric patterns of color which grow darker as they come close to the center. This is in keeping with the church's use of [[apophatic theology]], as described by [[Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite|Dionysius the Areopagite]] and others. As holiness increases, there is no way to depict its brightness except by darkness.
In architectural iconography, the frame of the mandorla is often marked with [[Molding (decorative)|decorative mouldings]]. The interior of the mandorla is usually undecorated, but may contain the symbols [[Alpha and Omega|Α and Ω]] or, less frequently, depictions of a starry sky or clouds.
In a famous romanesque fresco of Christ in Glory at [[Sant Climent de Taüll]], the inscription ''Ego Sum Lux Mundi'' ("I Am the Light of the World") is incorporated in the mandorla design.<ref>http://www.xtec.es/~jarrimad/medieval/romanico/taull.htm</ref>
The [[tympanum (architecture)|tympanum]] at [[Conques]] has Christ, with a gesture carved in [[romanesque sculpture]], indicate the angels at his feet bearing candlesticks. Six surrounding stars, resembling blossoming flowers, indicate the known planets including the [[Moon]]. Here the symbolism implies Christ as the [[Sun God|Sun]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.handinaute.org/roman.img/Conques02.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-10-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007071716/http://www.handinaute.org/roman.img/Conques02.jpg |archivedate=2007-10-07 |df= }}</ref>
In one special case, at Cervon ([[Nièvre]]), Christ is seated surrounded by eight stars, resembling blossoming flowers.<ref>http://homepage.uvt.nl/~s239062/EDIFICES/cervon/CERVONtim.JPG{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> At Conques the flowers are six-petalled. At Cervon, where the almond motif is repeated in the rim of the mandorla, they are five-petalled, as are almond flowers—the first flowers to appear at the end of winter, even before the leaves of the almond tree. The symbolism of the nine-branched [[Chanukkiyah]] candelabrum may be relevant. In the 12th century a great school of [[Judaism|Judaic]] thought radiated from [[Narbonne]], coinciding with the origins of the [[Kabbalah]].<ref name="ref5">{{cite book |last=Scholem |first=Gershom |authorlink=Gershom Scholem |title=Origins of the Kabbalah |publisher=Princeton Paperback |year=1990 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9dRi8v-j7OMC&printsec=frontcover&q |isbn=0-691-07314-7}}</ref> Furthermore, at Cervon the eight star/flower only is six petalled: the Root of David, the Morningstar, mentioned at the close of [[Book of Revelation]] (22:16).<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20160808231625/http://www.romanes.com/Cervon/Saint_Barthelemy_de_Cervon_0011.html</ref> (In one of the oldest manuscripts of the complete [[Hebrew Bible]], the [[Leningrad Codex]], one finds the [[Star of David]] imbedded in an octagon.)
In the symbolism of [[Hildegard of Bingen]] the mandorla refers to the [[Cosmos]].<ref name="ref6">{{cite book | last = Riedel | first = Ingrid | title = Hildegard von Bingen, Prophetin der kosmischen Weisheit | publisher = Kreuz Verlag, Zürich | year = 1994 }}</ref>

In [[music cognition]] and [[musical analysis]], the study of '''melodic expectation''' considers the engagement of the brain's predictive mechanisms in response to music.<ref name="Margulis2007"/> For example, if the ascending musical partial [[octave]] "do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-..." is heard, listeners familiar with Western music will have a strong expectation to hear or provide one more note, "do", to complete the octave.
Melodic expectation can be considered at the [[Esthesic and poietic|esthesic level]],<ref name="Nattiez1990">{{cite book |author=Jean-Jacques Nattiez | publisher =Princeton University Press |date= 1992 |title=Music and Discourse: Toward a Semiology of Music (Musicologie générale et sémiologie), translated by Carolyn Abbate | isbn=978-0-691-02714-2}}</ref> in which case the focus lies on the listener and its response to music.<ref name="Margulis2007"/> It can be considered at the [[neutral level]],<ref name="Nattiez1990"/> in which case the focus switches to the actual musical content, such as the "printed notes themselves".<ref name="EN1992"/> At the neutral level, the observer may consider logical implications projected onto future elements by past elements<ref name="EN1990"/><ref name = "SC5"/> or derive statistical observations from [[information theory]].<ref name="Youngblood1958"/>
==A multifaceted concept==
The notion of melodic expectation has prompted the existence of a corpus of studies in which authors often choose to provide their own terminology in place of using the literature's.<ref name = "SC5"/> This results in an important number of different terms that all point towards the phenomenon of musical expectation:<ref name = "SC5"/><ref name="MMF2006">{{cite web |author=Morwaread M. Farbood | publisher = Massachusetts Institute of Technology |date=2006 | url=http://www.al-edu.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/MaryFarbood-A-Quantitative-Parametric-Model-of-Musical-Tension-PhD-Thesis-2006.pdf |title=A quantitative, parametric model of musical tension, submitted to the Program in Media Arts and Sciences, School of Architecture and Planning, in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Tod Machover, supervisor) | accessdate=2014-11-12}}</ref>
* Anticipation.<ref name="Levy2003">{{cite web |author= Fabien Lévy| publisher = Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales |date=2004 | url=http://recherche.ircam.fr/equipes/repmus/Rapports/TheseFabLevy.pdf |title= Complexité grammatologique et complexité aperceptive en musique, submitted in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy at the EHESS (Jean-Marc Chouvel, Marc Chemillier, directors) | accessdate=2014-11-11 |language=French}}</ref><ref name="Thompson2007">{{cite web |author=William F. Thompson | publisher = Empirical Musicology Review, II/2| date=2007 | url=http://asage.org/index.php/ASAGE/article/viewFile/137/66 |title= David Huron, Sweet anticipation: music and the psychology of expectation | accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Huron2006"/> * Arousal.<ref name="Meyer1957">{{cite journal |author= Leonard B. Meyer | publisher = Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism, XV/4|date=1957 |title=Meaning in music and information theory | jstor = 427154}}</ref> * Deduction.<ref name="EN2000" /> * Directionality.<ref name="Arlettaz2000">{{cite book |author= Vincent Arlettaz | publisher = Sprimont, Pierre Mardaga Editeur |date= 2000 |title= Musica Ficta, une histoire des sensibles du XIIIe au XVIe siècle |isbn=978-2870097274|language=French}}</ref><ref name="Lester2002">{{cite book |author= Joel Lester | publisher = Cambridge University Press |date= 2002 |title= Rameau and eighteenth-century harmonic theory, The Cambridge History of Western Music Theory, directed by Thomas Christensen |isbn=9780521686983}}</ref><ref name="EHM2005"/> * Expectancy, expectation, expectedness, and in French ''attente''.<ref name="Margulis2007">{{cite journal |author= Elizabeth H. Margulis |date= 2007| url=http://mts.oxfordjournals.org/content/29/2/197.short |title=Surprise and Listening Ahead: Analytical Engagements with Musical Tendencies | journal = Music Theory Spectrum|volume= 29 |issue= 2|pages= 197–217| accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes| doi = 10.1525/mts.2007.29.2.197}}</ref><ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Abdallah2009">{{cite journal |author1=Samer Abdallah |author2=Mark Plumbley |lastauthoramp=yes |date=2009 | url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09540090902733756#.VGFvl_SG-R0 |title=Information dynamics: patterns of expectation and surprise in the perception of music | accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes | doi=10.1080/09540090902733756 | volume=21 |issue=2–3 | journal=Connection Science | pages=89–117}}</ref><ref name="Aiello2007">{{cite web |author=Rita Aiello | publisher = Empirical Musicology Review, II/2 |date=2007 | url=http://asage.org/index.php/ASAGE/article/viewFile/137/66 |title= David Huron, Sweet anticipation: music and the psychology of expectation| accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name ="Bharucha1993">{{cite book |author=Jamshed J. Bharucha | publisher =Oxford University Press |date=1993 |title= Tonality and Expectation, in Musical Perceptions pp. 213-239, edited by Rita Aiello | isbn=9780195064766}}</ref><ref name="Bharucha1987"/><ref name="Carlsen1981">{{cite web |author=James C. Carlsen | publisher =Psychomusicology, I|date=1981 | url=http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/pmu/1/1/12/ |title=Some factors which influence melodic expectancy | accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Cuddy1995">{{cite journal |author1=Lola Cuddy |author2=Carole Lunney |lastauthoramp=yes |date=1995 |title=Expectancies Generated by Melodic Intervals: Perceptual Judgments of Melodic Continuity |journal=Perception & Psychophysics |volume=57 |issue=4 |pages=451–462 |doi=10.3758/BF03213071 }}</ref><ref name="Schmukler1989">{{cite journal |author=Mark A. Schmukler | publisher =Music Perception, VII |date=1989 |title=Expectation in music: Investigation of melodic and harmonic processes | jstor =40285454 }}</ref><ref name="Sadai1986">{{cite journal |author= Yizhak Sadaï| publisher = International Review of the Aesthetics and Sociology of Music, XVII/2|date=1986 |title= Les aspects systémiques et énigmatiques de la musique tonale, points d'appui et points d'interrogation |language=French| jstor = 836671}}</ref><ref name="EGS1996"/><ref name="EGS1997"/> * Facilitation.<ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="EHM2005"/><ref name="Bharucha1987">{{cite journal |author= Jamshed J. Bharucha | publisher =Music Perception: An Interdisciplinary Journal, V/1 |date=1987 |title=Music Cognition and Perceptual Facilitation: A Connectionist Framework | jstor =40285384 }}</ref> * Implication / realization.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="EN2000" /><ref name="EHM2005"/><ref name="Cumming1992">{{cite journal |author=Naomi Cumming |date=1992 |title=Eugene Narmour's Theory of Melody | jstor = 854031}}</ref><ref name="Snyder2001">{{cite book |author=Bob Snyder | publisher =M.I.T Press |date=2001 |title= Music and Memory|isbn=9780262692373}}</ref> * Implication (independent from realization).<ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Bharucha1987"/> * Induction.<ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="EN2000" /> * Inertia.<ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Aiello2007"/><ref name="Larson2005">{{cite journal |author1=Steve Larson |author2=Leigh Vanhandel |lastauthoramp=yes | date=2005 |title=Measuring musical forces |journal=Music Perception |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=119–136 |doi=10.1525/mp.2005.23.2.119 }}</ref> * Musical force(s).<ref name="Larson2005"/> * Previsibility, predictibility and prediction.<ref name="Youngblood1958">{{cite journal |author=Joseph E. Youngblood | publisher = Journal of Music Theory, II/1 |date=1958 |title=Style as information | jstor = 842928 }}</ref><ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Aiello2007"/><ref name="Hiller1967">{{cite journal |author1=Lejaren Hiller |author2=Ramon Fuller |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher =Journal of Music Theory, XI/1 |date=1967 |title= Structure and Information in Webern's Symphonie, Op. 21 |jstor=842949 }}</ref><ref name="Knopoff1981">{{cite journal |author=Leon Knopoff et William Hutchinson | publisher =Journal of Music Theory, 25th Anniversary Issue, XXV/1 |date=1981 |title=Information theory for music continua | jstor =843465 }}</ref><ref name="Margulis2008">{{cite journal |author=Elizabeth H. Margulis et Andrew P. Beatty |title=Musical style, psychoaesthetics, and prospects for entropy as an analytic tool | journal = Computer Music Journal |volume=32 |issue=4 |pages=64–78 | doi = 10.1162/comj.2008.32.4.64 | year = 2008 }}</ref><ref name="Snyder1990">{{cite journal |author=John L. Snyder | publisher = Music Theory Spectrum, XII/1 |date=1990 |title=Entropy as a measure of musical style: the influence of a priori assumptions | jstor = 746148 }}</ref> * Resolution.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Arlettaz2000"/><ref name="EHM2005"/><ref name="Bharucha1987"/><ref name="Sadai1986"/><ref name="Cumming1992"/><ref name="RushtonGrove">{{cite web |author=Julie Rushton | publisher = Grove Music Online |title=Resolution |url=http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/23234 | accessdate=2013-07-01|subscription=yes}}</ref> * Tension / release, tension / relaxation.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Aiello2007"/><ref name="GTTM"/> * Closure, which may be used as the ending of the expectation process,<ref name="Margulis2007"/><ref name="Agawu1992">{{cite journal |author= Kofi Agawu| publisher = Music Analysis, XI/1 |date=1992 |title=Theory and Practice in the Analysis of the Nineteenth-Century Lied | jstor = 854301 }}</ref> as a group boundary,<ref name="Snyder2001"/> or as both simultaneously.<ref name="GTTM"/>
Expectation can also be found mentioned in relation to concepts originating from the field of [[information theory]] such as [[entropy]].<ref name="Youngblood1958"/><ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Abdallah2009"/><ref name="Hiller1967"/><ref name="Knopoff1981"/><ref name="Margulis2008"/><ref name="Snyder1990"/> Hybridization of information theory and humanities results in the birth of yet other notions, particularly variations upon the notion of entropy modified for the need of description of musical content.<ref name="Culpepper2010">{{cite web |author=Sarah E. Culpepper | publisher =The University of Iowa |date= | url=http://ir.uiowa.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1844&context=etd |title= Musical time and information theory entropy, submitted in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the Master of Arts degree in Music in the Graduate College of The University of Iowa| accessdate=2014-11-11}}</ref>
Consideration of musical expectation can be sorted into four trends.<ref name = "SC5"/>
* A first trend may include publications written in the 1950s by Meyer, Younblood and Krahenbuehl & Coons that are concerned with objectivization and rationalization of the concepts of arousal, uncertainty, or non-confirmation of a prediction using information theory.<ref name="Youngblood1958"/><ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Krahenbuehl1959">{{cite journal |author1=David Krahenbuehl |author2=Edgar Coons |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher =Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism, XVII/4 |date=1959 |title= Information as a measure of experience in music|jstor=428224 }}</ref> * A second trend may concern the more recent publications that include a step-by-step music analysis process at the neutral level, such as the [[generative theory of tonal music]]<ref name="GTTM"/> and Narmour's [[Implication-Realization]] model.<ref name="EN1992"/><ref name="EN1990"/> * A third trend may provide quantitative models based on computer algorithms, such as Margulis' model of melodic expectation or Farbood's model of musical tension.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="EHM2005"/> * A fourth trend may group generalist theories whose focus lies neither in step-by-step processes nor in quantitative operations, and may include elements pertinent to the esthesic level such as cognition and neurophysiology. This includes Larson's "musical forces"<ref name="Larson2005"/> and Huron's theory of general expectation.<ref name="Huron2006">{{cite book |author=David Huron | publisher =M.I.T. Press |date=2006 |title=Sweet anticipation: music and the psychology of expectation | isbn= 9780262582780}}</ref>
== Leonard Meyer ==
[[Leonard B. Meyer|Leonard Meyer]]'s ''Emotion and Meaning in Music''<ref name="Meyer">{{cite book|author=Leonard B. Meyer | publisher = Chicago University Press |date=1956 | title= Emotion and Meaning in Music |isbn=978-0-226-52139-8}}</ref> is the classic text in music expectation.{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}} Meyer's starting point is the belief that the experience of music (as a listener) is derived from one's emotions and feelings about the music, which themselves are a function of relationships within the music itself. Meyer writes that listeners bring with them a vast body of musical experiences that, as one listens to a piece, conditions one's response to that piece as it unfolds. Meyer argued that music's evocative power derives from its capacity to generate, suspend, prolongate, or violate these expectations.
Meyer models listener expectation in two levels. On a perceptual level, Meyer draws on [[Gestalt psychology]] to explain how listeners build mental representations of auditory phenomena. Above this raw perceptual level, Meyer argues that learning shapes (and re-shapes) one's expectations over time.
== Generative Theory of Tonal Music (GTTM) == {{main|generative theory of tonal music}}
== Implication-Realization model == {{main|Implication-Realization}} Narmour's (1992) Implication-Realization (I-R) Model is a detailed formalization based on Meyer's work on expectation.{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}} A fundamental difference between Narmour's models and most theories of expectation lies in the author's conviction according to which a genuine theory should be formulated in falsifiable terms. According to Narmour, prior knowledge of musical expectation is based too heavily upon percepts, introspection and internalization, which bring insoluble epistemological problems.<ref name="EN1992"/> The theory focuses on how ''implicative intervals'' set up expectations for certain ''realizations'' to follow. The [[Implication-Realization|I-R]] model includes two primary factors: proximity and direction.<ref name="EN1992"/><ref name="EN1990"/><ref name="EGS1996">{{cite journal|author=E. Glenn Schellenberg |date=1996 | title= Expectancy in melody: tests of the implication-realization model |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0010027795006656|subscription=yes |doi=10.1016/0010-0277(95)00665-6 |pmid=8808327 |volume=58 |issue=1 |journal=Cognition |pages=75–125}}</ref><ref name="EGS1997">{{cite journal|author=E. Glenn Schellenberg | publisher = Music Perception: An Interdisciplinary Journal, XIV/3 |date=1997 | title= Simplifying the Implication-Realization Model of Melodic Expectancy | jstor = 40285723 }}</ref> [[Fred Lerdahl|Lerdahl]] extended the system by developing a tonal [[pitch space]] and adding a stability factor (based on [[Generative theory of tonal music|Lerdahl's prior work]]) and a mobility factor.<ref name="FL2001">{{cite book|author=Fred Lerdahl | publisher = Oxford University Press |date=2001 | title= Tonal Pitch Space |isbn= 978-0-19-505834-5}}</ref>
== Bimbot and al.'s System & Contrast model ==
Mainly developed at [http://www.irisa.fr/en/ IRISA] since 2011 by Frédéric Bimbot and Emmanuel Deruty, the system & contrast or S&C model of implication<ref name="SC5">{{cite web |author1=Emmanuel Deruty, Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Brigitte van Wymeersch |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher = INRIA/Université Catholique de Louvain |date=2013 | url=https://hal.inria.fr/hal-00965914 |title=Methodological and musicological investigation of the System & Contrast model for musical form description |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC1">{{cite web |author1=Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Emmanuel Deruty |author3=Gabriel Sargent |author4=Emmanuel Vincent | publisher = INRIA |date=2012 | url=http://hal.inria.fr/hal-00868398 |title= System & Contrast: A Polymorphous Model Of The Inner Organization Of Structural Segments Within Music Pieces |pages=40 |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC2">{{cite web |author1=Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Emmanuel Deruty |author3=Gabriel Sargent |author4=Emmanuel Vincent | publisher = INRIA |date=June 2012 | url=https://hal.inria.fr/hal-00713196 |title= Complementary report to the Article "Semiotic structure labeling of music pieces: concepts, methods and annotation conventions" (Proceedings ISMIR 2012) |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC3">{{cite web |author1=Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Emmanuel Deruty |author3=Gabriel Sargent |author4=Emmanuel Vincent | publisher = ISMIR |date= October 2012 | url=http://ismir2012.ismir.net/event/papers/235_ISMIR_2012.pdf |title=Semiotic structure labeling of music pieces: concepts, methods and annotation conventions |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC4">{{cite web |author= Frédéric Bimbot, Gabriel Sargent, Emmanuel Deruty Corentin Guichaoua and Emmanuel Vincent| publisher = AES |date=January 2014 | url=http://www.aes.org/e-lib/browse.cfm?elib=17115 |title=Semiotic Description Of Music Structure : An Introduction To The Quaero/Metiss Structural Annotations |accessdate=2014-11-09|subscription=yes}}</ref> derives from the two fundamental hypotheses underlying the I-R model.<ref name="EN1990">{{cite book|author=Eugene Narmour | publisher = University of Chicago Press |date=1990 | title= The Analysis and Cognition of Basic Melodic Structures: The Implication-Realization Model|isbn=978-0-226-56845-4}}</ref> It is rooted in Narmour's conviction according to which any model of expectation should be expressed in logical, falsifiable terms.<ref name="EN1992">{{cite book|author=Eugene Narmour | publisher = University of Chicago Press |date=1992 | title= The Analysis and Cognition of Melodic Complexity: the Implication-Realization model|isbn=978-0-226-56842-3}}</ref> It operates at the neutral level and differs from the I-R model in several regards:
* while Narmour's two fundamental hypotheses address the relations between three elements,<ref name="EN1990"/> the fundamental hypotheses leading to the S&C model address the relations between four elements. Therefore, it can be considered as more directly suited to the classical ''sentence'' and ''period'' forms,<ref name="Caplin">{{cite book|author=William E. Caplin | publisher = Oxford University Press |date=1998 | title= Classical Form: A Theory of Formal Functions for the Instrumental Music of Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven |isbn=978-0195143997}}</ref> as well as to popular music forms;<ref name = "SC5"/><ref name="SC2"/> * while Narmour's I-R model addresses one-dimensional relations,<ref name = "SC5"/><ref name="EN2000">{{cite journal|author=Eugene Narmour | publisher = Music Perception, XVII/3 |date=2000 | title= Music expectation by cognitive rule-mapping | jstor = 40285821 }}</ref> the S&C model includes relations on two potentially independent dimensions; * the S&C model may encompass all aspects of the musical language, not only the melodic structure.<ref name="SC5"/><ref name="SC1"/><ref name="SC2"/><ref name="SC3"/><ref name="SC4"/>
== Margulis's model of melodic expectation ==
Margulis's 2005 model<ref name="EHM2005">{{cite journal|author=Elizabeth H. Margulis |date=2005 | title= A model of melodic expectation | journal = Music Perception: An Interdisciplinary Journal |volume=22 |issue=4 |pages=663–714 | doi = 10.1525/mp.2005.22.4.663 }}</ref> further extends the I-R model. First, Margulis added a melodic attraction factor, from some of Lerdahl's work. Second, while the I-R model relies on a single (local) interval to establish an implication (an expectation), Margulis attempts to model intervalic (local) expectation as well as more deeply schematic (global) expectation. For this, Margulis relies on Lerdahl's and Jackendoff's GTTM<ref name="GTTM">{{cite book|author1=Fred Lerdhal |author2=Ray Jackendoff |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher = MIT Press |date=1983 | title= A Generative Theory of Tonal Music |isbn=978-0-262-62107-6}}</ref> to provide a time-span reduction. At each hierarchical level (a different time scale) in the reduction, Margulis applies her model. These separate levels of analysis are combined through averaging, with each level weighted according to values derived from the time-span reduction. Finally, Margulis's model is explicit and realizable, and yields quantitative output. The output - melodic expectation at each time instant - is a single function of time.
Margulis's model describes three distinct types of listener reactions, each derived from listener-experienced ''tension'': *Surprise-Tension: inversely proportional to degree of expectancy; results in intensity or dynamism. *Denial-Tension: proportional to the discrepancy between the expectancy of the most expected event and the expectancy of the actually perceived event; results in desire, drive, will. *Expectancy-Tension: proportional to the degree of expectancy of the most expected event (in other words, if the listener had no idea what to expect next, the expectancy-tension would be low); results in strain or yearning.<ref name="MMF2006"/>
